tool module¶

tool.apply_perturbation(hs)¶

Apply perturbation to the snow depth to simulate the measurement error and do the data augumentation.

Parameters:

hs (pandas.core.series.Series) – The input data (snow depth) need to apply perturbation.

Returns:

perturbed_depth: The output seires after applying perturbation according to the 2017 WMO’s guidelines.

Return type:

pandas.core.series.Series

tool.cal_attr(attr)¶

Calculate the mean and sum of Integrated Gradients attributions for the given attributions.

Parameters:

attr (numpy.ndarray or a list) – Attributions tensor calculating from Integrated Gradients methods.

Returns:

tuple of (mean_attr, sum_attr) - Mean and sum of the attributions across the specified dimensions.

Return type:

tuple of (torch.Tensor, torch.Tensor)

tool.cal_integrated_gradients(model, X)¶

Calculate the Integrated Gradients attribution for the given model and input data.

Parameters:

  • model (torch.nn.Module) – The trained model whose attributions being calculated.

  • X (torch.Tensor) – The input data of which feature attributions being computed.

Returns:

attr, which is the attributions for each feature in the input data.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

tool.evaluate_model(test_loader, model, dataset)¶

Evaluate the trained model by calculating MSE, KGE, MAE and R^2 score, and plot the difference between the true values and the predicted values.

Parameters:

  • test_loader (torch.utils.data.DataLoader) – The dataloader contain the test data.

  • model (torch.nn.Module) – The trained model.

  • dataset (class object) – An object containing methods for inversing the data scaling.

Returns:

Tuple of RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error), MAE (Mean Absolute Error), MBE (Mean Bias Error), KGE (Kling-Gupta Efficiency), and R^2 score, true test data (y_test_ori) and predicted data (test_pred).

Return type:

tuple(float, float, float, float, float, np.array, np.array)

tool.grid_search(hyper_para, df=None, df_test=None, train_file=None, test_file=None, var=['HS'], ts=30, hidden_dims=[50], num_epochs=60, step_size=10, gamma=0.5, lr=0.001, is_early_stop=True, threshold=20, hyper_type='ts')¶

Conduct grid search over given hyper-parameters and plots the performance metrics.

Notes: 1. This function will loop over the provided hyperparameter values, train a model for each,

and then plot performance metrics (RMSE, MAE, MBE, KGE, R2) for the models.

  1. If ‘hyper_type’ is set to “ts”, the grid search will be performed over different time series lengths. If set to “architecture”, the grid search will be performed over different LSTM architectures.

Parameters:

  • hyper_para (list) – List of hyperparameters values to search over.

  • df (pandas.Dataframe, optional) – The input data to train the model, default is None. (Either df or train_file must be provided, but not both.)

  • df_test (pandas.Dataframe, optional) – The input data to test the model, default is None. (Either df_test or test_file must be provided, but not both.)

  • train_file (str, optional) – The csv file path to load the data for training, default is None.

  • test_file (str, optional) – The csv file path to load the data for testing, default is None.

  • var (list, optional) – The features required for training, default is [‘HS’].

  • ts (int, optional) – The time sequence length, the number of time steps to be considered in model, default is 30.

  • hidden_dims (list, optional) – The dimensionality of hidden layers, default is [60, 30].

  • num_epochs (int, optional) – The number of epoches runs for training, default is 60.

  • step_size (int, optional) – Step size for the learning rate scheduler. Default is 10.

  • gamma (float, optional) – Factor of learning rate decay. Default is 0.5.

  • is_early_stop (bool, optional) – Whether to use early stopping during training. Default is True.

  • threshold (int, optional) – Threshold for early stopping. Default is 20.

  • hyper_type (str, optional) – Type of hyperparameters to search over, default is ‘ts’.

tool.kge(real, pred)¶

Calculate the value of Kling-Gupta Efficiency.

Parameters:

  • real (numpy.array or list) – The true test data.

  • pred (numpy.array or list) – The predicted test data.

Returns:

kge: The calculated value of Kling-Gupta Efficiency.

Return type:

float

Calculate the mean bias error.

Parameters:

  • y_true (numpy.ndarray) – The true value of target variable.

  • y_pred (numpy.ndarray) – The predicted value of target variable.

Returns:

Mean bias error of the target variable.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

tool.minmax_data(data, dtype='train', scaler=None)¶

Apply Min-Max Scaler to the training and testing data (to the range 0-1).

Parameters:

  • data (dataframe) – The input data needed to scale.

  • dtype (str, optional) – The type of input data, choose train or test, default is train.

  • scaler (sklearn.preprocessing.Scaler, optional) – The scaler used to scale the data, default is None.

Returns:

(data_norm, scaler): The tuple of scaled data and the corresponding scaler.

Return type:

tuple

Plot the diagram to show the global snow classification according to snow classification scheme introduced by (Liston and Sturm 2021) and stations.

tool.plot_time_series(true_values, predictions_1, predictions_2=None, dates=None)¶

Plots the true and predicted SWE values over time.

Parameters:

  • true_values (numpy.array or list) – The ground truth SWE values.

  • predictions_1 (numpy.array or list) – The predicted SWE values.

  • predictions_2 (numpy.array or list, optional) – The second predicted SWE values.

  • dates (list, optional) – The dates corresponding to the values. If None, will use integer indices.

tool.rebuild_data(df, var, ts=30)¶

Rebuild the input data into the required shape of LSTM.

The input data should contain the following columns (Col names should be the same.): - ‘loc’: Identifying the location. - ‘date’: The timestamp associated with each sample. - ‘station_SWE’: The target values for estimating.

Parameters:

  • df (dataframe) – The input data needed to rebuild.

  • var (list) – The features selected in rebuilding.

  • ts (int, optinal) – The time sequence length, the number of time steps to be considered in model, default is 30.

Returns:

(input_values, target_values): The tuple of input_values(X) and target_values(Y).

Return type:

tuple

tool.split_dataset(X, Y, test_size=0.2, random_state=42)¶

Splitting the dataset into training and validation set.

Parameters:

  • X (dataframe) – The input data (X).

  • Y (list) – The target data (Y)

  • test_size (float, optinal) – The proportion to include in the test part, default is 0.2.

  • random_state (int or None, optinal) – The seed used to control the shuffling, default is 42.

Returns:

(X_train, X_val, y_train, y_val): The tuple of X_train, X_val, y_train, y_val.

Return type:

tuple

tool.standardise_data(data, dtype='train', scaler=None)¶

Apply Strandard Scaler to the training and testing data (to the range from -1 to 1).

Parameters:

  • data (dataframe) – The input data needed to scale.

  • dtype (str, optional) – The type of input data, choose train or test, default is train.

  • scaler (sklearn.preprocessing.Scaler, optional) – The scaler used to scale the data, default is None.

Returns:

(data_norm, scaler): The tuple of scaled data and the corresponding scaler.

Return type:

tuple

tool.t_test(perf_null, perf_modif)¶

Perform t-test between two samples of performance metrics and interpret the result.

Parameters:

  • perf_null (list) – Performance metrics (e.g RMSE) from the original method.

  • perf_modif (list) – Performance metrics (e.g RMSE) from the modified model.

tool.train(df=None, df_test=None, train_file=None, test_file=None, var=['HS'], hidden_dims=[60, 30], num_epochs=60, step_size=10, gamma=0.5, ts=30, lr=0.001, is_early_stop=True, threshold=20)¶

Trains an LSTM model using the training data and parameters, then plot the loss function, and evaluate it on the testing set.

Notes: This function performs the following steps: 1. Data pre-processing: Converts dataframes or files into sweData. 2. Model building: Initialises an LSTM model with the given parameters. 3. Training: Trains the model using the training data. 4. Loss plotting: Plots the training and validation losses over epochs. 5. Evaluation: Evaluates the model performance on the test data.

Parameters:

  • df (pandas.Dataframe, optional) – The input data to train the model, default is None. (Either df or train_file must be provided, but not both.)

  • df_test (pandas.Dataframe, optional) – The input data to test the model, default is None. (Either df_test or test_file must be provided, but not both.)

  • train_file (str, optional) – The csv file path to load the data for training, default is None.

  • test_file (str, optional) – The csv file path to load the data for testing, default is None.

  • var (list, optional) – The features required for training, default is [‘HS’].

  • hidden_dims (list, optional) – The dimensionality of hidden layers, default is [60, 30].

  • num_epochs (int, optional) – The number of epoches runs for training, default is 60.

  • step_size (int, optional) – Step size for the learning rate scheduler. Default is 10.

  • gamma (float, optional) – Factor of learning rate decay. Default is 0.5.

  • ts (int, optional) – The time sequence length, the number of time steps to be considered in model, default is 30.

  • lr (float, optional) – The initial learning rate, default is 0.001.

  • is_early_stop (bool, optional) – Whether to use early stopping during training. Default is True.

  • threshold (int, optional) – Threshold for early stopping. Default is 20.

Returns:

Trained LSTM model, RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error), MAE (Mean Absolute Error), MBE (Mean Bias Error), KGE (Kling-Gupta Efficiency), and R^2 score.

Return type:

tuple(torch.nn.Module, float, float, float, float, float)
